div.p: hi everyone I'm Cathy ding and i'm here
to talk to you about inclusion so a lot
of times people will say things about
hack night like wow it's like really
diverse like like there are a lot of
like men and women in the room and like
their developers and designers and
government people and data people but I
and actually i hack night is a lot
better than the vast majority of tech
meetups but I just want to like push
back on this kind of self-congratulation
because just counting bodies in the room
is like a really simplistic view of
inclusion the things that really
ultimately matter are how people are
participating and how people are
interacting with each other and that's
that's like a much much deeper thing um
so I've had a feeling for a long time
that hack night was actually very
male-dominated but that's just a feeling
and what's more fun than a subjected
feeling is objective data so let's see I
want to show you a new website that I
built you can get to it by bit ly it's
our men talking too much
ah and it's a timer and here you can say
ah right now a man is talking or up it's
not a man talking and then it'll show
the percentage right here um so I took
this for a trial run at hack night a few
weeks ago ah and does anyone want to
guess what it was now too embarrassed
okay well it was ninety-four percent men
and six or seven women and this isn't
even including Derek and Christopher by
the way I was only counting the parts of
hack night that are kind of uh none
moderated so things like announcements
and questions and things like that and
this is kind of crazy because these are
the types of things that are really hard
to pay attention to if you're not like
explicitly looking out for it like this
is something that men are like very bad
at noticing so yeah this is very bad and
I just want to remind everyone that the
most creative and successful projects at
hat night I think have been led by women
so there was the school cuts project
that was one that's really popular among
parents clearest project my building
doesn't recycle is a first hack night
project to actually like impact
policymaking which is amazing rose and
Genevieve started to M relief and now
that's a full-fledged nonprofit so who's
participating at hack night really
matters um so I made that are men
talking too much a website because what
gets measured gets managed this is the
idea that if you start quantifying
something oh you'll get better at it
because you're paying attention to it
and you're focusing on it um so my ask
of you is one I use my timer you can
also use it you know at meetings or
like I don't know where ever um and also
another ask is if you're the type of
person who talks a lot maybe before like
blurting things out just think a little
bit like think hey like is this worth
everyone's time should I be listening
instead should I give him a chance for
other people to talk and also I do want
to add that gender is just one small
type of inclusion it was just a simple
thing that I was able to focus on but I
really welcomed everyone else to come up
with your own hacks on your own small
projects to make heck night more
inclusive all right thanks
you
